Posted: July 8, 2012
												Torchlight is a well done action RPG dungeon crawler. Not original by any means, but its simplified interface makes it very user friendly and easy to pick up. Three different character choices plus you get a pet. There's plenty of random loot which is ultimately why we put so many hours into these type of games. At the end of the day though, it does end up feeling a little empty having to play alone.

Posted: June 3, 2011
												Torchlight - a hack n' slash RPG comparable to Diablo II. I suggest this game on Hard if you want challenge (Normal is pretty easy). You have a choise of a warrior, rogue, or mage class and while there is no visual customization beyond gear, you can mix and match skills or specialize skill trees without fear of having a skill requirement for any skill TL gets somethings right: pets can carry the same amount of items you can, and can be sent to town to sell them, a shift-click will transfer your items to and from inventories and merchants. pets can retreive loot. Though you can't change the keybindings (except mapping skills to 1-0 and F Keys), some parts ore either too easy or too hard, and quest loot if often junk. If you're into this kind of game, you'll get plenty of replay value for $14.99. 7/10 Score

Posted: September 29, 2015
												Not an alternative to Diablo or Path of Exile, if that is indeed what you are looking for. It is a much smaller game in scope and size, with a unique approach towards the genre. The combat is highly satisfying, the progression is intuitive, and the art style is pleasing to look at. You can easily switch your playstyle or try a different class if it becomes repetitive. The level design is somewhat random and not particularly great, but it never feels broken or out of place. The rest of the game is solid with not much to complain about. I never felt bored playing it, but I also never felt too engaged. I often found myself playing other games over Torchlight, or just forgetting about the game entirely. So in that sense it's not particularly memorable, but whenever I rediscover the game I end up enjoying it just as much as the last time I played it.

Posted: June 18, 2011
												*cough* Diablo *cough *TItan Quest *cough* Now that I have your attention, I don't really think I have to say anything else. The two games mentioned at the beginning of this mini review tell you exactly what you want to know. Yes, it's an action RPG (all the mouse clicking is probably going to hurt your fingers). And yes, there's random loot. I hear you think; does this game show us anything new then ? Well... yes. You now have a pet that's with you 24/7. Your pet can kill, keep items and even sell your items. The dungeons are randomly created, meaning a level won't ever be the same and their are enough vendors in town (enchanters, weapons, random maps, you name it) to keep you busy for a long, long time. And the graphics are superb, love the style ! Also, they could've set the difficulty a bit higher, because most of the times there isn't much of a challenge. But I'm sure they'll fix that in Torchlight II. Now... what are you still doing here ? Go play it ![Rating: 78/100]

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2012
												I never cared for Diablo, so it's a bit puzzling that I put so much time into Torchlight, a derivative made in part by makers of Diablo & D2. Most tout D2 over Torchlight due to its multiplayer/larger class variety, but Torchlight's interface addresses my problems with the genre.The main problem with ARPGs (esp. Blizzard's) is "tedium" & "excessive mouse clicking." Torchlight takes real measures to reduce both. You can hotkey commands to ALL keyboard numerals. You get an invincible pet that not only doubles your inventory, auto-attacks enemies, and can pick up items for you, but can be told "go back to town and sell your items to free up space." THIS IS HUGE. You're also CONSTANTLY getting new gear, which makes Normal mode a breeze. Alas, you still left-click to both move AND attack.As far as aesthetics, I prefer that in this game, you can dual-wield GUNS and effectively set up machinegun sentry turrets. Hits have impact. Enemies can be pretty massive. One's even a chaingun mecha!

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Bwee. So this is one of those dungeon-crawler games where you click an insane amount of times. Indeed, you move and attack with the same button. Now it's been a while since I played this, so I might be wrong about that, but I am pretty sure I am not. I've got a pretty good memory for things that annoy me. Another such thing was having -all- of my save data for this game lost on a crash shortly after beating the final boss, ensuring that I wouldn't touch it again.So why review this? Because reasons. I guess it's a good diablo-esque dungeon game. I wouldn't know. Ask people who actually like those sorts of games, because I'm not one of them. I'll give this a "yes" anyway because it's good at what it's supposed to do, even if it is stuff that I have little taste for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												A suitable ARPG to pass the time until Diablo III shows up, but there are a ton of glaring issues with Torchlight that prevent me from recommending it fully. For starters, the overall difficulty level is arbitrary, veering from too easy to extremely difficult in a matter of moments. Some monsters are impossible to kill without spamming unique abilities or spells, and oftentimes combat reverts to simply holding down a spell hotkey until spawning monsters are completely wiped out. The end boss is a supremely horrible example of game design, and the targeting system is far too finnicky to be of any accuracy - you have to click on the same tiny spot in order to target any opponent or else you'll miss completely. In addition, there are several game-breaking issues that can bring play to a halt and ruin a finely-tuned character forever.Not a bad game by any means, just poorly designed and executed by the developers. Hopefully Torchlight 2 makes up for all of this.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												I cannot in good faith recommend this to any fantasy or dungeon-crawler junkies.Yes, I know, it was made by former Blizzard (Diablo, WoW) Employees, and they set out to make a better game.They failed.-You cannot reliably fight on stairs, you always miss with spells.-Dungeons and Loot are randomized, making tracking down armor sets a complete chore.-Killing wave after wave of enemies gets VERY boring after about 10 floors of monotony.-The set-up ideas and setting are interesting, but so watered down you don't care in the end.-Main male npc dies in battle at the start.-Main female npc does NOTHING for the entire game, despite being a "seasoned veteran hero".-"Evil Wizard that wants immortality being whispered to by a dark deity/spirit/monster" cliche.-On the 30th floor SUDDENLY enemies show up that can challenge you, blast away 2/3 to 4/5 of your HP in one hit, shifting the difficulty of the game drastically, regardless of what difficulty you're on.This game brings nothing new to the table, and the makers literally admitted they were making a Diablo 2 clone, but "better". You guys better shut your sacreligious mouths.((P.S. You can't leave Torchlight (the town) because some jackass parked a supply cart ON the bridge out of town. wth...))

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Some of the former Diablo 1 & 2 dev's who are now w/ Runic Games worked on this game, so expect more of the same - except MUCH more modernized in many ways (graphics, interface, etc). While the story is nothing spectacular (like many game in this ARPG genre) and the voice-acting is decent enough, you are really here for the addictive nature of the awesome combat, constant upgrading of your character & the crazy amount of loot. TL is very similar to Diablo 1 in style, as you'll keep going down & down deeper into the dungeons to battle forces trying to corrupt & ruin the town. TL sports a steampunk setting & is much more colorful than Diablo. One cool thing about TL is you can have a pet join you in combat...and have it run back to town & sell items back to town so you can stay in the action! This game is Single Player only, BTW. Torchlight is a great ARPG & very easy to reccommend to those who love ARPG's with constant action, character upgrading & tons of loot.Grade = B+

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												While the story is different, the gameplay and game mechanics seem, to me at least, to be almost IDENTICAL to the old Diablo II game that Blizzard released over a decade ago.  I mean, everything from how you move and attack (left mouse to attack, shift+left  mouse to stationary attack), to the hack-n-slash style of the game's quests, to the scrolls of Town Portal, to socketed weapons and armor, to a three-pronged, Mana-powered skill tree, to the...well, you get the idea: it plays a lot like the old Diablo II game.  So, I guess one could argue that it's a Diablo II rip-off (and they may be right), but it's an extremely well made, easy to learn, fun to play game so it's hard to judge Torchlight too harshly.  I loved Diablo II and despite (or maybe because of?) the similarities, I'm having a ball with this game so far.  It's totally worth buying (especially on sale).  Yes, the story is pretty simplistic, but if you want a fun, doesn't-take-itself-too-seriously, hack-n-slash adventure game, then this is your ticket!  :)  Plus, the cartoony graphics sort of add to the charm of the game.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												*click*click*click*That's what you're going to be doing ALOT of in Torchlight.The game is an old school hack-and-slash RPG in the same vein as the Diablo series and all the clones that have spawned from that. Players who enjoy those kinds of games and/or are loot and stat junkies will absolutely adore Torchlight however everyone else will probably run out of steam once the main "story" is completed. There's tons of loot ranging from common stuff to rare items and sets of items to track down, you have three character types to choose from (the basic three: warrior, rogue, and wizard who each have three skill trees), you've got a pet that will carry loot and even transform into different things when you feed it fish, the different sections of the dungeon are artistically well done, and the range of enemies is definitely substantial.  Other than being a solid dungeon crawler though there's not much else to attract those who aren't quite fans of that genre. The story is paper thin, theres absolutely no characterization in regards to your own avatar or the very few NPCs, the sidequests are uninspired (get this, kill that, go to a different dungeon and get this) and the whole thing just feels like a time sink - one that will definitely appeal to some but will leave others bored and ready to move on to something else after a couple of hours.The best way to really describe Torchlight: you're going to love it or hate it. Unfortunately I tend to put a good deal of emphasis on narrative, the game world, etc and this game just straight up doesn't have that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2013
												Probably one of the best RPG games I've played. Much like Diablo, Torchlight brings forth a similar dungeon crawler play style with a third-person point and click system. However,unlike Diablo, the in-game system is much different. Take the fighting system for example, Diablo has a very straight forward story line. This requires the player to follow everything that is expected of them. In Torchlight, there are quests that can alter the path of the rest of the game. Character customization is huge in these types of games. Diablo forces you to choose from a few lousy skills, whereas in Torchlight, there is an abundance of spells and skills to choose from. I can probably rant for another few hundred words comparing the two games, but I don't want to denounce Diablo too much because I also play the Diablo series (or used to anyways). Although it says that I have 0 hours played on this account, I did play an insane amount of this game... Trust me, I'm a professional.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2011
												To put it simple the game is a traditional Diablo clone, but a real fun one, not to mention it has an official editor which allows to create awesome mods - starting with some new unique weapon additions ending with total conversions. The gameplay... well, you pretty much just smash and inicerate all the foes on your way, collect new equipment (Most of which you sell - most of stuff you find is not worth equiping) and level your character, unlocking new abilities. These are real fun and different for all three classes. You also get a dog (Or cat, or something weirder if you get a specific mod)  which can be sent to town to sell all the junk you don't need - works great for a speedrun. All the levels are randomly generated (That's what makes any Hack'n'Slash game so unrepeatable and fun) and all the locations look great. Only issue is that weapons and abilities are bit unbalanced - dual wield is best, 2-hands suck. Graphics are simple but neat and remind me of Warcraft 3.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
Torchlight adds nothing new to an already stale genre.Pros: Graphics, Sound, ControlsCons: Story, GameplayTorchlight hits all the basics very well.  The graphics are varied and colorful, the sound and music are fitting and sharp, and the controls are simple and effective.Torchlight's story and gameplay, however, fall short.  Our hero will massacre thousands of creatures in order to save a couple of humans the trouble of moving.  The gameplay only matches the story's blandness.  Combat consists of clicking things, although this is par for the genre.  The leveling system offers too few new abilities or mechanics but instead too many stat dump options.  The loot system is largely irrelevant: equip anything with more stats, sell the rest.  The enemy variety means little after facing hundreds of the same things.Unfortunately, Torchlight never manages to shine with its nearly nonexistent story and boring gameplay.6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2013
												So I've played Diablo 3 a ton and wanted to check out Torchlight since all the D3 haters say this is the real Diablo. Wait, hold on... why is game even more colorful than D3, I thought it would be all dark and scary like Diablo. Also where's my god damned guided arrow, I'm an Amazon for christ's sake. Er, I mean... a Vanquisher. Oh well I guess this ricochet shot will do, and let's not forget to max the passive critical buff, criticals are awesome. Let's continue deeper down.Sigh. The bottom rows of my inventory is literally filled with potions, Identify and Town Portal scrolls and managing all of it is making me crazy. Like stacks of 20? Seriously? I know Diablo had it as well but that was not why I loved that game. Anyway, I ain't picking up more of that♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'll just buy it from the vendor. If only my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cat could teleport me back to town... I did teach him a friggin Town Portal spell after all. I mean what else is he supposed to do, he'll start fleeing immediately when engaged in combat.Um... why am I finding guns? This is not Dungeon Siege. Diablo had no guns. Oh great, now that I'm not picking up useless items anymore, I can't even see when I get rare or unique items because they're all hidden behind white trash and you need to be a surgical tech to pick them up. Honestly I can't even pick up what I want without picking up trash in the process so I'm just going to spam the click button.Yay, final boss time. I kinda rushed through the later game and I'm fighting him at level 25. 												I believe the best description of Torchlight would be Diablo II for kids. I say this because many of the features, from the automap and music to the item sounds and classifications, are all evidence of the developers' previous works, which indeed includes Diablo II. I see this game as a kind of introduction to the type of game it is, whereas Diablo II is its apex. Despite my "for kids" label, this game is nevertheless fun and definitely worth playing. Coming from someone who has played Diablo II for years, this game constantly reminds me of its predecessor. If you like to play a Diablo II-like game, but without the dark, horror backdrop, this is a great game with which to begin your adventure.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Torchlight torchlight torchlight. I remember when this game first came out. Remember too? The graphics were just plain ugly even back then.Torchlight's history in short is that most of the Dev team worked on Diablo 1, 2 and every expansion in between. And that is exactly what makes Torchlight a complete failure.From the very first second I played it, I didn't like anything. The style, the visuals, the setting.... It feels rushed and unfinished. Normally I do a Pro v Con list but there are no Pros here, so here are just the worst things about Torchlight.- Linear Gameplay: I can't stress this enough, It may very well be the only thing that's absolutely wrong with this game but it's a big one. Ever played a 2D platformer, like Mario? Well that's just about as linear as you can get. Just go from start to finish, no deviation in between. To have something like that in a 3D game is... is...what? Why? But that's what Torchlight is, constantly. You go down and then you follow the path, follow it, kill every enemy you see and keep following the path.- Music: Well the town music is very similar if not the same as in Diablo 1 and 2. Because they hired the same guy to make the soundtrack. It shows, it isn't good. They probably thought that it'd be nice to have music that sounds the same as a far superior game. But by doing so, they hit the same note when an awful movie refers to a better movie during the movie.- Classes: Three character classes...? This is an RPG right? What kind of RPG only has 3 classes? Maybe Torchlight isn't the only one, but it should be. There really isn't an excuse for that, most RPGs already have the same classes over and over. But Torchlight takes the most generic 3 classes too, Melee Ranged and Wizard/SummonerNone of which are any fun while running towards the next level down.- Graphics: I'm not a graphic freak, I honestly don't care about them, choppy framerate? I'm probably the last person to notice, but these GFX?! No! Just no, why is everything squareish? Was the Dev team all like "We need something round but a dodecahedron is easier to draw." I don't think so, don't like itFinal verdict, Torchlight is nothing more than a Diablo clone. But I've played several clones in my day, this is by far the worst one. Torchlight feels like an empty vessel, like a game without a soul. It has no identity other than the one it tries to be. I heard that the sequel is far better.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												Torchlight is a 3d hack-and-slash modeled after games in the Diablo series. If you’re not familiar with that, it’s basically a lot of left clicking, dungeon roaming, and loads of looting. It’s hard to talk about this game without referencing Diablo, as even the music seems like it was pulled straight from that game and the visuals are reminiscent of the third game with their vibrant colors and auras.Torchlight adds to the familiar mechanic by giving you a pet that acts as both a defender and pack mule, able to be sent back to town to sell all your loot at a moment’s notice leaving you to continue looting and pillaging. There’s also a fame system that acts as a second “experience” meter and gives you a skill point for every level you gain in addition to skill points given by actual experience levels. Unfortunately, this game lacks a sense of excitement regarding gear. Frequently on my play-through I would see unique and set items drop, giving me a momentary rush that was quickly extinguished upon identification. It’s sad to say that I ended up simply buying and enchanting the majority of my gear in town, meaning the dungeon crawl was more of a means of gathering gold and experience to fuel my character development topside. It was about 20 or so hours before I finally got my first decent weapon drop…from the game’s final boss. The only use for it then was to do the infinite dungeons the game offers afterwards. Since Torchlight has no multiplayer, there was nobody to show the cool weapon to either. Some other grievances: the storyline isn’t particularly engaging and the bosses are barely memorable save for the one that caused tremors and the big bad at the end. The game also has an issue with the Z-axis and projectiles in many levels, making your attacks hit stairways and ramps inconsistently, even when you directly target an enemy (this is incredibly annoying). Lack of multiplayer was a serious oversight IMO as the thing I remember the most with the very first Diablo game was hundreds of hours spent playing alongside friends and randoms online. Torchlight isn’t a terrible game, but it’s not really good enough for me to recommend when there are so many other games around that do the same thing way better.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Torchlight: a dull glowI played Torchlight way back when it first came out, circa 2009. I enjoyed it, but there were some things that just nagged at me while I played it. Unfortunately, the more I played it, the less I liked it. Going further and further into the game did not increase my enjoyment. And I ultimately stopped playing.Sadly that perfectly describes my most recent experience with Torchlight.I’ve tried to figure out just what it is that I don’t like, but every time I formulate my thoughts I come up with the same conclusion:The game feels hollow and generic.It doesn’t seem to have it’s own identity or stand out as unique from other games in the ARPG genre. Hell, Torchlight is essentially an “HD remake” of Diablo from 1996… without the “Hell.” The game follows the same basic progression and is, in many ways the same game, but with less of an edge.I feel that really hurts Torchlight.Plenty of games can be fun without a cool in-game world or a “gritty” story hook to pull you in. It’s gameplay that matters in the end, right? Sadly I think that Torchlight also falls flat here as well.Torchlight is pretty a pretty shallow game, to its detriment. Killing monsters is fun in its own right, but only for so long. Other ARPGs alleviate this by giving you things to work for: new more powerful items, more powerful skills, harder challenges, etc. Torchlight does have all of these things… they’re just not interesting. So although the game does have the “carrot on a stick” incentive to continue playing… I’m, sadly, not interested in the carrot.I found the gameplay to be rather lackluster and boring. Torchlight’s art style does not appeal to me. The environments lacked feeling, and ultimately felt sterile. The items in the game were shallow, and only the “unique” items had any flavor. The various character skills weren’t very impressive, and didn’t feel very powerful.But let’s break down the individual pieces of Torchlight and critique it against the five points I mentioned previously.Atmosphere and StoryAtmospherethe pervading tone or mood of a place, situation, or work of art.Torchlight has little to no atmosphere. Certain areas in the game look pretty darn cool, but carry absolutely no feeling.My favorite areas are a necropolis found underneath the mines beneath Torchlight (Yes, that’s the name of the town) and the underground jungle-temple ruins beneath the necropolis. Why I like these two areas over all the others? Probably because they have the most ‘flavor’. But even then it’s spread pretty thin.There isn’t much to be said about the game’s various locales other than that they don’t make much sense and require a bit too much suspension of disbelief for my taste.Storyan account of imaginary or real people and events told for entertainment.I consider story to be tied very closely with atmosphere, and like Torchlight’s atmosphere, there isn’t really much to be said about the story. It’s pretty generic and could be summarized in two sentences: “Torchlight was built over a corrupted source of magic caused by an ancient evil deep within the Earth. Go kill it.”More accurately: The town of Torchlight is mining a substance called Ember, which allows for the various forms of magic in the world, but it turns out the Ember under Torchlight is corrupt and will turn anyone who comes into contact with it evil! This is because the Ember Vein runs over an ancient evil, later revealed to be a dragon. You are called to Torchlight to help the mining operation, which is being attacked by monsters, but are promptly betrayed by the man who summoned you. As it turns out he wants to revive the dragon sleeping beneath Torchlight. And you, the hero, have to stop him by traveling deeper and deeper into the Earth uncovering older and older civilizations that fell to the corrupting allure of the Ember.Pretty good ideas! Not going to lie, there’s definitely a cool story in there. But it’s really only used as an occasional spur to remind you to continue murdering monsters as you travel what seems like miles into the earth. A shame, really.There is very little involvement in the story, and to be honest the voice acting is pretty hammy. If you like that sort of thing, then good on ya! I had to skip most of it.But hey, atleast you can skip it! Actually all of it! Which is nice.Enemiesthe persons who are actively opposed or hostile to someone or something.Unfortunately, the enemies in torchlight are boring. There isn’t any way around it. I don’t like their designs, and none of them really seem to have any interesting mechanics to differentiate them. They’re all just bigger and bigger punching bags. Some will revive their comrades, and some will leave noxious fumes after death. But by and large, the majority of them are meat sacks that fling their bodies against your weapons.It doesn’t help that the enemies have massive spikes in difficulty towards the end of the game. There is a LARGE increase in enemy health and damage in the last area. And every time I’ve played, it has come as a shock.I’ll be doing just fine, then I’ll walk into the last section of the game and be murdered. Only to find that I’m unable to deal significant damage to the enemies. Their scaling seems to be off, and it’s just not fun.Your Characterthe representation or expression of something in a tangible or visible form.Torchlight utilizes the typical stat system. Your RPG standards are all present: Strength, Dexterity, Magic, Life, and Defense. Every time you level, the game gives you five points to allocate to each of these different parameters. Unfortunately it seems like the various stat points are really just a way of directing your progression. It didn’t seem as though loading a bunch of points into Magic made my Alchemist’s magic any more powerful, despite it being his main damage stat. It seemed as though it was just a holdover from previous games. “Diablo had them, so Torchlight will too.”Really the stats just felt like numbers I had to inflate in order to put on different armor. My character’s power seemed to be located in the weapons and armor he was wearing rather than the character himself.Skillsskill or expertise in a particular activity or fieldTorchlight also follows a rather traditional skill tree format, present in almost every ARPG. Ever.That’s perfectly fine. Skill trees are used so commonly because they work. Sadly, the skills in Torchlight are boring. Plain and simple. The coolest spells I got for my Alchemist were Chain Lightning and a laser. Everything else rather boring.I think that is was a major contributing factor to why Torchlight felt boring to me. The three different classes all had pretty boring skills. Nothing really stands out, and everything felt pretty lame.Itemizationthe balance and distribution of items, their types, and the various effects, powers, and statistics attached to themLast but not least, the items. Again, there isn’t a lot to say. Torchlight’s items were rather lacking. Most items are of the, “+10 fire damage,” “+20 lightning damage,” “+5% attack speed” variety. Nothing to write home about.This is probably the one aspect of the game where Torchlight tried its hardest to please me.I received about 7 unique items before reaching level 15. Unique items are Torchlight’s highest rarity item, apparently. They were all decent, and some of the unique wands I found had cool effects that altered combat, like shots bouncing and releasing arcs of electricity on the ground. But they were little more than more powerful versions of the base items. Not particularly exciting.Boring skills, boring monsters, boring items, boring combat.Very sad indeed.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												This game is about 10 hours too long. It was fairly entertaining at first, but constantly having to clear out my inventory soon became a tedious chore. The story and setting didn't do a good job of drawing me in - it felt like they weren't even trying. I was never really challenged to change up my play style - I basically got through the game spamming the same couple of attacks over and over, and had no major problems. The last boss took forever, and you'd think they'd at least throw in a decent ending after that, but no, just a quick "thank you" and you're unceremoniously dumped back into the world.I suppose overall it's fairly well made for what it is, so maybe I just don't like the genre, but for all the time it took, I never found it particularly rewarding, so I can't really recommend it.

number of helpful: 13 of 30 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												In Torchlight, you are drawn to a town, also called Torchlight, where a magical ore called Ember is mined. As you move down through the dungeon, you learn that Ember has a corrupting effect on any who use it, and has led to the downfall of a number of civilizations before yours. It's not the deepest story in the history of RPGs, but it is clear that the developers put real effort into it. The writing is miles better than that of many other hack & slash games I've played as well. The same can't really be said of the sidequests, which follow the exact pattern from Fate: your task is always to kill a specific boss and/or retrieve a specific piece of loot, with little real reason given. I don't think of this as a significant problem, though. Instead, I think it's pretty standard for action games.Torchlight may only be above average in the story department, but its gameplay is outstanding. It takes good ideas from the developers' previous games and improves on them in just about every way possible. There are three character classes (essentially, a barbarian, a ranged character, and a magician), each of which plays very differently from the others, and each of which can be viably developed in several ways as you level up. For example, my first character was a magician who focused almost entirely on summoning, similar to Diablo II's Necromancer. I could have put my points into casting spells, though, and been more similar to the Sorceress.Each class has three skill trees, although certain skills like "ranged weapons mastery" show up in the trees of all classes. I appreciated that, since I wanted my summoner to dual-wield pistols – something he's not necessarily good at by default. In addition, there are magic scrolls, found as loot or purchased, that allow you to teach certain skills to any character. I loved having that ability, because it allowed my barbarian to cast town portal spells and identify magical items; skills that many RPGs restrict to the magician class.In Torchlight, your character is constantly accompanied by a pet dog or cat. You can catch fish and feed them to your pet to change them (temporarily or permanently) into another animal/monster, and I was overjoyed to see that Torchlight doesn't make you waste inventory space on a fishing pole to do so. Your pet levels up along with you, and it can wear two rings and a necklace, which is nice. The pet also has an inventory, can be directed to pick things up, and can be sent back to town at any point to sell loot. Doing so really helps keep the game flowing because like any good hack & slash game, you'll pick up a lot of loot, and going back to town to sell it is annoying.Your pet doesn't just serve as a pack mule, though, or even as simply a meat shield. You can also teach it any of the spells learned from scrolls. It can only learn two spells, but the pet AI makes good use of whatever you give it. I liked my cat to be able to summon zombies and leech health from attacks, but a dog who can throw fireballs and heal the whole party sounds pretty awesome too.The main story takes you down through one long dungeon to a final boss battle, but once you've beaten it, a second, never-ending, randomly generated dungeon is unlocked where the monsters scale to your current level, so you can keep playing with the same character as long as you want. In addition, maps can be purchased from vendors that take you to shorter randomly generated dungeons. These serve as a nice break from the main storyline or even a place to grind for levels and loot if you ever find yourself in need of doing so. Interestingly, there are also random monsters called "phase beasts" that open a portal to a one-level dungeon when killed. Again, the only reason to go to these dungeons is to get loot and experience, but they seem to give good loot, so they are worth the time.There are a hundred other things I could talk about in terms of gameplay, but I won't. Instead, I'll limit myself to four brief things I can't leave out of my review. One: you can install gems in your equipable items, and when you're ready to upgrade something, you can destroy the gems and keep the item or vice versa. I would have loved this in Diablo II, where I agonized over actually using all of those runes I collected. Two: each character has their own inventory, their pet's inventory, a private stash in town, and a stash that they share with all of your other characters. If you love to hoard items, this is a dream come true, because it makes passing items between characters and creating "mule" characters a breeze. Three: Torchlight is designed to make modding easy. It's reportedly a piece of cake to create mods, and I can confirm that it takes almost zero effort to install them. There are a lot of mods out there, and they range from the classic "I'm lazy, so I'll break the game's balance" to simple, but really nice, things like changing the opacity of the mini-map. I even installed a mod that unlocks a ferret as a third pet option. Four: when you look at weapons in your inventory, you're shown their attack speed and the damage they do, but you're also shown their DPS (damage per second), which is a huge help when deciding whether to trade up to a new weapon.There is one thing missing in Torchlight's gameplay, though: multiplayer. I rarely play games online, so I didn't miss it, but I know that this may be a deal-breaker for some gamers. It stands up very well as a single-player experience, though, so if you're interested in this kind of game, I'd urge you to give it a shot despite that lack.Graphically, Torchlight made me very happy as well. It's not that this is the prettiest game you'll ever see, because it's no Crysis. It's that it looks great on even a lousy setup like mine. There's even a "netbook" mode to allow machines even weaker than mine to play.The game really does look good. Spell effects are plentiful, and weapons that do elemental damage throw the appropriate sparks, flames, or snow. The environments are rendered in full 3D, and use the classic overhead isometric camera. Like any game with that camera, it has to deal with the issue of environmental elements getting in the way, and Torchlight's solution is to render a sort of x-ray version of the character. Friends are blue, enemies are red, which really helps. Stylistically, it falls halfway between Fate and Diablo II.This game sounds great, both in terms of music and sound effects. Certain sounds are almost identical to their Diablo II counterparts, but that is so common in this type of game that I find it hard to criticize. My only true complaint is that when your pet gets injured, they whine, which can be annoying if they're surrounded by a huge pack of enemies.Torchlight controls very simply, but in a good way. You click on the ground to move or on enemies to attack them, and I like the fact that it's fairly forgiving. If you are pretty close to an enemy when you click, you'll attack, which really helps when dealing with fast-moving enemies. Skills, scrolls, and potions can be assigned to slots for the 1-0 buttons on your keyboard. You can equip two sets of weapons and switch between them at any time by pressing W, which came in handy for me on many occasions. Buttons are assigned to your inventory, your skill tree, etc., but they're easily accessible through on-screen icons as well. It isn't groundbreaking, it's just a good implementation of tried-and-true controls.In the broadest terms, there are two ways to make a great game: do something cool that hasn't been done before, or do a great job of improving on things that have been done before. Torchlight falls pretty firmly in the second category, but that doesn't make it any less great.Highly Recommended

												Torchlight is bizarre in that it introduces a lot to the genre that is very convenient (larger inventories and smaller items, shared character stashes, minimizing town runs to the bare minimum), but the entire game is anemic to the point of boredom. It lays the groundwork for the genre's future, but is not a good game at all.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												A good first attempt at a Action RPG but just does not excell at anythingGenre: Diablo clone/action RPGYea! -Cartoonish art direction is nice.-Pet companion is useful.-Decent story- Nice varitiy of enviromentsMeh!-Combat feels extemely slow and simple comapred to Diablo 3.Not much in the terms of equipment stats variation means you could use same piece of gear for quite a long time. -Not much depth, basically you spam most powerful attack and potion when needed from start to end, there is no need to change tactics at allBleh!: -The last boss is nothing but a test of patience then skill, has too much health and takes quite a long time to windle down as you run circles around him popping potions.-Even though you have quite a few skills to learn, expect to only use 1 or 2 and ignore the restLowdown:Torchlight at release before D3 would of been the goto game but after the release it just seems average. Combat seems like it takes forever and needs no real type of skill. You expect a dungeon crawler where the main premise is to keep upgrading gear to get better but Torchlight seems to fail at this as new gear for my character came far and few between. I ended up ending the game with a level 10 piece of gear at level 36 because it had better stats then anything i could find. At least your pet can hike this stuff back to town to vendor for you, giving him more then the benefit of a lowly ai companion And last the final boss was a letdown due to the fact that he is easy to deal with but the devs just gave him absurd amounts of health that took a long time to windle down. The game does offer great art style that is pleasing to the eyes and never gets dull as the enviroment changes often. 2.5/5**From what I heard TL2 improves on a lot that made this game average so it is best to go for that instead of this one if you want a Diablo 3 alternative**

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Reviewing Torchlight is a tough one for me. It’s not a buggy game, everything works very efficiently, and the graphics and sounds have a clear unity to them. But I will never ever touch to this game again if possible. It doesn’t have any charm, the setting is dull beyond all belief, the identity it tries to build falls flat, the combat is exhaustingly boring, and the item hoarding reached its new pointless peak. Like I said there’s a unity to the graphics but they possess no appeal whatsoever. They’re just there. They don’t add anything to the game — certainly not atmosphere. Everything looks like a kiddy cartoon and strips the experience from any emotion there was left. You never find anything useful in the dungeons. I bought everything I used and only gathered stuff to sell it. The spells are useless. I wanted a mage but ended up using the special skill that by the way don’t get bonuses from your skills that you can level up. The levels are so repetitive that I barely noticed when their themes changed. The general jist of it was: switch the doodads around a bit and put up different color wallpapers. Then there are the end bosses which bring the word “boring” to a new level. It’s just running and grinding. For minutes. Or in the case of the final boss possibly HOURS (I can’t know for sure because I had to use cheat codes to get through it before I fell asleep). This game does so many things wrong that it doesn’t deserve any sort of recognition. It is just horrible.

												Torchlight is a fairly mediocre diablo-like. I haven't played much of the diablo games so I would take this review with a grain of salt. I may just not like the genre. The levels feel bland, similar, and uninspiried. The characters felt different, but it seemed that all of them mostly ended up just pressing on of a few buttons until an enemy died. I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												This is a truly brilliant game for grinding. It has so much grinding in it, the publishers had better sell a physical version packaged with grindstones.On the other hand, if you prefer grinding, this game also has something for you. For instance, I tried placing a handful of black peppercorns on my desk while playing, and guess what - 3 hours later I found them ground to dust, perfect for cooking! Amazing!For the extreme gamers among us: you like listening to grindcore while grinding? With this game, you no longer need to! You immediately reach equivalent amounts of adrenaline and dopamine just by firing up the game. And when you start playi--sorry, grinding--oh boy, oh boy, the joy, the brain ground into nirvana!Last but not least, Torchlight II is a great continuation of the grind included herein, so your grinding in the first Torchlight will have its well-deserved sequelae of repetitive grind in the second.Can only recommend this to any and all grinders.

content:
Posted: January 6
												Playing through as an Arcane Alchemist on Normal, I was enjoying myself for the first 8 hours. The next 8 hours after that, it became clear that if I wanted to progress at a reasonable rate, I would have to do some grinding. In a game that I actually like, grinding would be acceptable even though I think it's a stupid way for someone to progress in a game. Torchlight's endgame was complete garbage and I would not recommend this game to anyone. There are numerous problems with the spellcasting in this game like: not being able to cast up/down stairs properly, not being able to cast depending on what hand your casting from when there's a very small and almost non-existent object next to you, having to wait between casts (meaning if you want to drink a potion, do a buff, then cast, you have to wait until each animation is completely finished before you can do the next. This makes intense combat scenarios extremely annoying to get through when you have to shuffle between these things) and so much more. I could complain about this all day but I'll just end it here.Torchlight is not fun, it's annoying (as said before.) I beat the game and I'm obviously salty as all hell, but I had to get this out. Stay away from this trash heap of an RPG.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Very basic Diablo clone with childish graphics and no atmosphere whatsoever that can be fun—for the first few hours anyway.The first few hours are quite fun due to its basic structure, which is very like the first Diablo (single town with a dungeon under it).  It can be addictive building up your character, and the game provides a decent amount of ways to power up outside of simply gaining levels.  You can attach gems to equipment, try to have equipment enchanted (and risk having all enchantments removed), and buy random equipment that could turn out to be enchanted.Unfortunately, there are way too many things holding this game back.First, the graphics and atmosphere.  It was designed to run on netbooks so the graphics are very simple.  That doesn't bother me so much... but the cartoony exaggerated look that couldn't be more generic means you'll be playing this for the mechanics only (more on that later).  The music, composed by the guy who did the music for Diablo 1 & 2, is just alright.  It sounds a lot like Diablo, but not nearly as good as Diablo.Second, the itemization is poor.  I found my best equipment not even halfway through the game on Hard.  Outside of finding rings that would give me +8 Dex vs +6 Dex, I had basically the same equipment loadout for the last 6 hours or so.  Nothing that dropped even came close to what I already had.Third, the dungeons are dull and feel way too long.  You have a mine, spooky castle, lava place, spookier castle.  That's about it.  The layouts are randomly assembled from larger pieces, but there is nothing whatsoever interesting.  Other than randomly coming upon merchants and bosses, there is nothing to look forward to or be surprised by as you explore.  Some unique hand-crafted rooms or levels or something would have gone a long way.  You have to go through 35 of these to beat the last boss, and once the item drops got boring so did the rest of the game.Fourth, the enemy variety is awful.  You typically have 2-3 enemy types per level.  Usually a small fast monster that just charges at you, an archer or wizard hanging back shooting spells, and a big tough monster that slowly comes after you.  That is basically it.  Each type of enemy will have some unique abilities (such as "shoots fire" or "stun resistant") but most of it is window dressing.  The bosses are just HP-inflated monsters that summon minions over and over.Fifth, the game is way too easy.  Diablo clones need to strike a good balance between being difficult and unfair, and need to give you access to skills and tactics that let you push the odds in your favor.  The only time I had any difficulty here (note: I played on Hard, which I know is code for "Normal" in this game) was in the last couple levels where they would routinely spawn demons that could basically instantly drop a two-hit kill spell on me.  If you die you can resurrect in town with no penalty, resurrect at the start of the level with some gold missing, or resurrect in place with a gold and exp penalty.  So in other words, there is really no penalty for dying, and once I learned that I totally lost interest in the game.All in all, a skeleton of a decent Diablo clone is here (as Torchlight II would go on to prove), but considering the competition (including the original Diablo which has actually aged remarkably well), Torchlight is a hard game to recommend to nearly anyone.

Posted: January 25, 2011
												Torchlight is, in every way, the successor to Diablo 1. It's a stylish Action RPG where you control either a warrior, rogue or wizard and venture into a randomly-generated dungeon. Torchlight improves on Diablo in that, in addition to your hero, you control a pet that has its own inventory and can be sent back to town while you are adventuring to sell all the goods that it is carrying. Torchlight will provide you with many hours of entertainment, although, much like Diablo, it can get somewhat repetitive.

												The gameplay is phenomenal, hack-and-slack at its finest. Quests are average, just enough to pull a Cobb. Multiplayer was promised and never delivered. If you want a very fun single player Action-RPG, buy it, otherwise wait for Torchlight 2!

Posted: December 22, 2010
												I played Torchlight for nearly 100 hours - very addictive hack-n-slash dungeon crawler. If you like Diablo, you should like this. The guy who did music for Diablo made the music for Torchlight - and it shows - amazing atmospheric music. They also really came up with solutions to many of the problems of action RPGs. For instance, the problem of having to slog back to town to sell your junk and get some gold. They give you a pet that fights alongside you (and can shape shift) that has an inventory - you can send it off to town to sell your items and come back with gold. So you get to enjoy the dungeon more - I stacked a bunch of enchants that made my pet leave and come back instantly, so I never had to go to town unless I wanted to buy something.They also let you buy a respec potion if you have the gold. It is also very mod-able. There are mods making your pet into a giant ferret or adding a new special dungeon or quest giver or a treasure vault.Highly recommended.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												When Blizzard North - the original creators of Diablo and Diablo II - wanted to start development of the third installment of the series they had a concept in mind, the concept of an MMO styled Diablo, years before World of Warcraft, in the era of Ultima Online, UO might have had a true competitor in a sprite world rather then in the 3D age.Alas it was not the desire of the company to follow that path for the series, and so several members of Blizzard North decided to go their own way. In time Runic Games was founded and with it came the true sequel game of the Diablo franchise, albeit disguised with a different name. It's name was Torchlight, and it was incredible.With the recent release of Diablo III now it's the best time to evaluate and see how different these games are. For an avid player of the previous Diablo II, the official sequel never quite felt 100% in place, now pick up Torchlight or the upcoming Torchlight II and you feel the difference right away.

Posted: July 10, 2013
												Made in large part by former Blizzard North employees, Torchlight 1 can be boiled down to a remake of Diablo 1. You're limited to a single town, forced to battle your way underground to kill an ancient evil, collecting loot and leveling up along the way. Torchlight doesn't stop there though, the loot and skills are much more fleshed out than D1, and there are infinite dungeons ingame thanks to maps that open portals to them. While the main quest is short, you can do new game +, but the main draw is the infinite dungeons. All in all a great remake of a great game, provided the cartoony visuals don't bother you too much.

Posted: May 30, 2012
												Torchlight was the Diablo everyone was waiting for when there were none left to be found. It has all the best from the genre with none of the negatives.There is random loot aplenty, your character develops significantly as you proceed through the game, you can combine gems to make them more powerful, and unique to this torchlight, you can even gamble on enchanting your gear; maybe it will become more powerful, maybe all of the enchants will be wiped away.Graphics are great, sound is great, and you'll enjoy every minute of it.4/5

Torchlight is better than most $50 games out there at a low end price that makes it an easy decision of whether you should buy it. So get to it.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												I would heartily recommend Torchlight to .....someone if they were approximately 10-12 years old and as long as they'd done their homework! Its easy, flashy,  harmless,  extremely superficial and an utter waste of time much like the entire "Diablo" formula. But that is often enough or at least  OK so to speak for a lot of people since it's based on gameplay that has a strongly addictive element especially for the naieve. I don't mean that arrogantly when I played my first computer game in 1982 it was the bee's knees... even if the dragon I was attacking on the screen was just a large number of "Ds and Xs" joined up! Now in the 21st century... if your sensibilities are for undemanding colour and movement the game will be a blast. Frankly, I found Torchlight shallow and often rather dull, especially some rather uninvolving levels deep in the mine where I plowed through enemies like I was harvesting a field of potatoes. To me it lacks something...best summed up as "context". Torchlight is shallow (rhymes with callow...oops). I want something more ....some emotional connectivity perhaps. I desire meaning, actual substance in the story, intellectual stimulation since I'm old and bored and graphics, colour and movement are just that. When it's all done right you get something special, something emotive and memorable. Challenging for a designer I know, my sensibilities get in the way of fun..oh well. Fun is however easy peasy, disposable but leads to jadedness. Torchlight has not a shread of "context" but it is likely to be fun at least.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												Torchlight isn't a game. It's an addiction.Everything about Torchlight is very simplistic. From the fighting (which is as simple as "point and click") to the story (which I barely remember after 20+ hrs. of gameplay). It becomes mindless, and after awhile Torchlight made me feel like a rat hitting a feeder bar. I'd *click, click, click* to kill monsters, hope for some good loot, and repeat. Playing on normal mode was perhaps a bit too easy, as I only ever died out of stupidity. Even the bosses were very easy, with the exception of the final boss who was entirely unbalanced with the rest of the game.Though I'm glad I'm now free of its grasp, I must admit that I had fun playing Torchlight. Any RPG expert will have fun balancing player, pet, and weapon/armor stats, but the actual gameplay and story will remain a bit dull.My rating: 3/5

Posted: March 11, 2013
												Torchlight was developed by some of the guys who worked on Diablo 1 & 2. It's essentially very similar gameplay, the most noticeable difference being how bright and colorful the game looks in comparison to Diablo. This may be a turn-off to some, and very welcome to others who are tired to the standard dark and brown color schemes in games these day. If you're unfamiliar with Diablo, Torchlight is still a very accessible game. ARPGs are quite easy to get the hang of, as far as controls go (clickclickclickclick Q 124356 etc.) It's rather slow-paced, which might bug some people as it starts to feel boring after a few hours in a play session. Having a pet companion helps make the single player descent less lonely/ Pets will fight by your side, and also sell any excess items you give it in town for you. Dungeons are somewhat randomly generated. Loot drops also varies.The game is quite easy on Normal difficulty due to the abundance of potion drops, and the ability to just spam the potion button when you are in trouble. You shouldn't expect to die very often at all. Although this might give the game a bit of a casual feel, it is still an enjoyable single player game that isn't overly lengthy. You can get a good 25 hours in. Don't expect much on the story front; it's rather bland and not very memorable. Besides, the core of the game is centered on loot. While this game is worth the price, you may want to shell out an extra $5 for the sequel, which, in addition to fixing how rigged potions worked, the slow pace, adds much more to the game with regards to loot, classes, monsters, skills, and importantly, multiplayer.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												This is my first game review since joining Steam, try not to rip me apart? :DAs someone who was more of a console gamer, I unfortunately had never gotten around to the the critically acclaimed RPG's like Diablo or Fate. That being said, I've done a little research and given thought to purchasing the titles; until I found Torchlight. This game has highly impressed me beyond what I gathered by first impressions. It has a familiar feel (err, in my case "look") to Diablo/Fate, yet brings a fresh spin to the mix. Picking up the game very recently, for a STEAL while on sale for $3.74, I haven't had a chance to drain too much time into it just yet. However, in the 3 hours that have literally flown by since playing I can say that I'm addicted. The combat is interactive and keeps you moving, items are bountiful and useful, main/side quests that actually feel rewarding, and lastly but not least the crisp, clean graphics. I can already tell that I'll be completing another 2 playthroughs with the other character classes and spending more time than what's healthy for me to grind out some of the achievements. TL;DR - I highly recommend this game for any RPG lover that's looking for a good dungeon crawler with replay!

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Torchlight is a nice change of pace from the Diablo series. As a clone, as everyone else will state, it holds up as a great clone to Diablo. It's a milder environment to Diablo which is actually a refreshing change of pace. Instead of always being gloomy it has lots of color and different environments. It has some annoying characters like Diablo but nothing overbearing (like the Dungeon Hunter series).What I love. The ability to send a pet back to town with your loot to sell and not have to worry about town porting over and over. Also, pets, love the pets. I wasn't big on the fishing aspect of the game but loved having a pet around me. I also love the thriving community of modders and the ease of applying mods to the game.What I don't like. I wish I had more control over the character customization and appearance. Thankfully we do have some mods that allow visual skin changes. I have my alchemist set with a black goatee. But it would be nice to choose the sexe of your role. This was a limitation in Diablo too until Diablo III but still something that bugs me.I've tried out all 3 roles and enjoyed each. My favorite is the alchemist but there is something for everyone. Highly recommended.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												I got into this game not too long after Diablo 3 came out. I was originally playing that, but the servers were such a nightmare that I gave up. I went looking around and came across this game. This game is a good substitute to Diablo 3. I would even go so far as to say that it is better than Diablo 3. Sure the fact that it isn't always on DRM is pretty awesome, but the game is just generally more fun to play. It isn't as complicated as older Diablos, and I never really found this game to be difficult, but I have a real soft spot for it.One of the best things about this game is the pet system. It is so satisfying to be able to go into a dungeon, pick up every bit of loot, and when my bag is full I can just send my cat back to town to sell it off. I love that I barely spent time in town while playing this game, and when I was in town it was because I purposefully chose to go back on my own.Probably the thing that holds this game back the most is that choices are pretty limited. There are only three playable characters, and the skill trees aren't all that robust. The magic system is cool, but it's a bit annoying to have to switch out scrolls all the time. If you're looking to replace Diablo 3 this is a good choice. It might not have the shine of the other one, but it has more heart and it is more fun to play. Plus the sequel is even better than this one.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Great game. I myself have never played Diablo or Diablo 2, but my friend tried this game out as well and loved it, stating that it was basically a Diablo clone. It's lots of fun, and especially fun for me, being what I call an "anti-social gamer". I like single-player RPG's that feel like an MMO, and that's what you get with this.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												Opinion: worth every cent of the $15 I paid originally, but on sale for less than $4? Buy this game! For that price I bought one as a gift and one for myself even tho I already have the game on disk with >L50 hero. The convenience of having it on Steam where I can play from any of the 3 computers I have access to is solid gold!Rating: 9/10.If you liked Diablo 1/2/3, you'll really enjoy TL! Looks like, plays like, and feels just like Diablo but with a pet (which gives you more inventory space, a way of getting rid of excess inventory without leaving the dungeon, as well as having another body to fight along with you)!Standard choices of hero: barbarian (melee), rogue (ranged), and magician (alchemist) altho you can customize all of these by using skill points to increase strength, dexterity, magic, and defense. Upgrade system for your armor or weapons by enchanting and socketing gems ("embers") just like Diablo. These gems can be refined to higher grades of purity, giving better bonuses to your armor or weapons. Also a way of recovering either the gem or the socketed item without harm, but you have to sacrifice one or the other.Tons of loot generated with no (white), one (green), or more buffs (blue), along with unique (orange) and set (purple) items that when matched to other items of that same set, give additional buffs to your hero.Randomly generated levels so each playthru is different, giving unlimited replayability. Excellent game with the best of Diablo mechanics, wrapped in smooth visuals and seamless gameplay. 5 stars! Buy this game!

Posted: February 18, 2012
												Like RPG's but aren't super hardcore?  Is WOW a too expensive and massive for you to get into and enjoy?  Do you like to play RPG's alone and not have to rely on guilds, clans, and raid parties to have fun?  In that case, Torchlight is for you.  It is a much simpler version of WOW: 3 classes and only 3 skill trees per character.  Your pet can run items to town to sell and you would think that would solve your inventory problem but you'd be wrong.  Slots in your pack become prime real estate which can get frustrating.  Surviving in dungeons is easy since you never run out of health or mana potions and it also means that you can spam your best skills indefinitely.  When I have the itch to play an RPG and watch numbers slowly increase and I don't have a saved Final Fantasy record to play, this is a great substitute rather than just re-opening a WOW account when that itch comes around like some people.  Start a record with each character though so you can switch when you get tired of one.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												It's like Diablo, but better. The only consideration is its cartoony look and feel, but that is overwhelmed by the superior gameplay in all regards.The choice of character classes is greatly simplified over Diablo's complex set-ups of different characters; in some sense, there is less of a sense of reward when you create this godlike monstrousity of a character, but in another sense it makes it a lot easier for the less meta-gaming player to play the game; its less about statistics than it is raw fun.The choice of pet is also not significant, but the decision on whether to send your pet back to town or keep him with you in whatever form you've specced and spelled him up to be is also significant.In fact now that I think about it, I've basically been playing a massively simplified single-player WoW for the last week, so...wow.BUY THE GAMEor torrent it if you have to, but its worth the buy

Posted: January 31, 2014
												I got into this game not too long after Diablo 3 came out. I was originally playing that, but the servers were such a nightmare that I gave up. I went looking around and came across this game. This game is a good substitute to Diablo 3. I would even go so far as to say that it is better than Diablo 3. Sure the fact that it isn't always on DRM is pretty awesome, but the game is just generally more fun to play. It isn't as complicated as older Diablos, and I never really found this game to be difficult, but I have a real soft spot for it.One of the best things about this game is the pet system. It is so satisfying to be able to go into a dungeon, pick up every bit of loot, and when my bag is full I can just send my cat back to town to sell it off. I love that I barely spent time in town while playing this game, and when I was in town it was because I purposefully chose to go back on my own.Probably the thing that holds this game back the most is that choices are pretty limited. There are only three playable characters, and the skill trees aren't all that robust. The magic system is cool, but it's a bit annoying to have to switch out scrolls all the time. If you're looking to replace Diablo 3 this is a good choice. It might not have the shine of the other one, but it has more heart and it is more fun to play. Plus the sequel is even better than this one.

												It's a diablo clone but cartoonier and tons of enemies.You pick as three classes to play as: the Mage/Alchemist, the tanky Destoyer and the ranged Vanquisher. There's a lot of weapons, enemies to kill and places to explore in Torchlight and the deeper you go underground, the more the scenery changes.It's a good time waster and doesnt have too steep of a learning curve and is laptop friendly aswell.As for the cons: The game does take place for the most part underground so you dont see much daylight. And no coop mode.Hopefully Torchlight 2 will fix some of these problems but for now it's a fun game you can just pick up and play.

Posted: July 18, 2012
												 Probably one of the best indie games out there. This game has got everything one might want from a hack-and-slash genre representative: flawless and fluent gameplay, excellent music (with a new "haunting guitar theme" (tm)), nice random-generated level design, interesting art-style. Now the game has no co-op, but I don't care since I only play single-player anyway. Another debatable issue are the models used for enemies. Some like them, others don't. I personally find them a bit funny and well-fitting for an adventure of this type. Those looking for more grim environments can always play Diablo series instead. Another problem might be a very primitive story, but that has, unfortunately, become "standard" for most hack-and-slashers these days. This game deserves 9 out of 10 at the very least and I eagerly anticipate part II (like many others).

Posted: July 22, 2012
												This is a great Hack'n Slash! However haing played Diablo II it is obvious to me where the developers got their inspiration. I don't mean that is a bad way, Diablo II is a grat game but Torchlight just takes everything from it, and I mean EVERYTHING. The skills tree and attributes work the same way and are in the exact same form and place, all potions and sockettable Items are the same, well everything is the same, even the music is very similar. I would call this game a RIP OFF if I didn't think Diablo's gameplay was so good it was meant to be copied in every way. I actually didn't feel like I was playing another game my first thought when I started was "oh I'm in tristram". In a strange way the better graphics and smarter interface makes me think much of the time this is simply an updated version of DIablo II. Anyway I can't criticise something I enjoy very much, and this is a really good game and I can only commend the people who made it for having chosen Diablo as a template.

Posted: March 17, 2011
												EDIT: Now that Torchlight 2 has released, I figured I should put a little update to this. This game still shines just as much as I wrote previously.. and if you like it, you should definately pick up the second game! So much more was added and it still retains all the things I loved from the first.OLD REVIEW: This is one of the best dungeon-crawlers I have played to date.  I like this game more than I like Diablo and Champions.  It is fresh, and since it is made by most of the original Diablo 2 team, they know what they are doing and they give players a game worth investing in.  Unlike most other dungeon-crawlers, this games only drawback is there is no multiplayer for it (but Torchlight 2 will be).  The story is good, graphics are pretty, and there are tons of levels to explore and monsters to vanquish.  The game supports fan-made mods, and so there is a ton of extra content you can get, varying from different classes, pets, items, levels, etc. I love it more than a fat kid loves pie.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												As a fan of Diablo and D2(LOD), this game is everything those 'should' have been.  One thing I should mention at the start, though:  I'm not positive, but I believe considering everything I've seen online, playing this game for extended periods can actually affect your hardware.  It may only be coincidence, but after playing this on my laptop for long periods, I noticed that my computer was starting to overheat to the point where it actually shut down.  Even on my current desktop system, I can actually hear my computer working hard to keep the game running.  It may be partially that my hardware isn't really capable of running the program at peak efficiency.  Anyways, with that out of the way, I love the game.  The character movement flows along very well, and with decent strategy, the game isn't too hard, but still presents challenges along the way.  And, there's still the extended levels which I have yet to explore (although it sounds like the tile sets are merely reproduced from the primary game levels).  A nit-pick is that it's sometime painstaking trying to conduct transactions with the various vendors (constantly moving back and forth, and with hovering descriptions obscuring the purchase screen).  The biggest advantages this offers over the Diablo games is the ability to save at any point, as well as being able to send your 'pet' back to town to sell off the junk items you collect along the way.  Another thing I like is that it's easier to collect pieces of equipment to complete a 'set' (unlike Diablo2, where I have yet to actually complete even a minor one).  Overall, I enjoy playing this little gem.

Fishing! Shared Stash!Cons-Multiplayer, this game has none in any way-Grind----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Torchlight is an excellent love letter to the diablo series, But it does lack a very key feature that hurts it and will turn many people off. Absolutely no multiplayer, This creates several issues with the game and it's systems. It makes getting any kind of major set you want extremely difficult and pretty much a luck based grind. If you can look past that you will find a great experience that feels like and improves upon the old classic Diablo.

												PROS:- Three solid classes- You can equip anything on anyone- You got a familiar with you- Your familiar has travelling pouches strapped on, which means you can send him to the store to sell excess items!- You can equip a few pieces of equipment on your pet, and magic as well- Passive skills can be obtained (so if you're like me, you'll prefer those to manual skills)- You have multiple difficulty levels to choose from- You can also select Hardcore mode, meaning you pick any difficulty plus hardcore (this means death is permanent)- Auto save (saves to Steam and locally)- Enemy deaths are permanent (for the most part)- Mods are available, yay!- Mod editor available (I haven't tried it though. Library --> Tools ---> Torchlight Editor)CONS:- Only three classes to choose from- Character customization in the beginning is very restrictive- Skills and so on are very limited- Magics are very restrictively used. You can only equip a limited amount- Part of the storyline is confusing- Story could have been better plotted- Only around 25 hours of gameplay- Only 3 main characters + 3 secondary characters + the townspeople/miners and salesmen- Music is not horrendous, but uninspired and makes gamplay somewhat boring

Posted: January 12, 2014
												This is my first game review since joining Steam, try not to rip me apart? :DAs someone who was more of a console gamer, I unfortunately had never gotten around to the the critically acclaimed RPG's like Diablo or Fate. That being said, I've done a little research and given thought to purchasing the titles; until I found Torchlight. This game has highly impressed me beyond what I gathered by first impressions. It has a familiar feel (err, in my case "look") to Diablo/Fate, yet brings a fresh spin to the mix. Picking up the game very recently, for a STEAL while on sale for $3.74, I haven't had a chance to drain too much time into it just yet. However, in the 3 hours that have literally flown by since playing I can say that I'm addicted. The combat is interactive and keeps you moving, items are bountiful and useful, main/side quests that actually feel rewarding, and lastly but not least the crisp, clean graphics. I can already tell that I'll be completing another 2 playthroughs with the other character classes and spending more time than what's healthy for me to grind out some of the achievements. TL;DR - I highly recommend this game for any RPG lover that's looking for a good dungeon crawler with replay!

												A really well polished and fun game. Same style as diablo. Your camera is over the top of the character and you go through a series of dungeons. You can choose between either a archer, mage or warrior. They each specialize in their respective fields but you can still slightly specialize in the other two as well. It combines elements from diablo and fate. There are different dungeons but instead of different areas to go to, you just go deeper and the areas change as you go. The boss fights are great as well. You dont feel like you are just fighting a harder npc. You feel like you are really fighting a boss. The look of the game is really great too. It has a sort of cartoony look to it. I think this is a great game and I highly recommend it. The only setback is the lack of mulitplayer.

Posted: July 13, 2012
												With a linear, framework for a story, "Torchlight" has straight-forward "click on everything" gameplay with a skill tree. Hearing the announcer / narrator intone when one has levelled up adds to the feeling of accomplishment. Lots of loot with variety is available throughout the dungeons, but also not mind-numbing to gather sufficient pieces to make sets. The best part is the low system requirements; while saving money to get a nice computer, I was able to play "Torchlight" on a netbook.There are a few recurring bugs, such as getting stuck against the environment, especially in the "pocket universes" accessed via scrolls and a particular monster; the only way to get out of this glitch is to use a console command.This game's sequel is in development and you can get this first game for free along with the sequel... or buy it at various retailers for a very affordable US$10.I recommend this game if you enjoy the "Diablo" series, "Titan Quest", "Throne of Darkness" or "Prince of Qin".

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Since I'm not a big fan of Diablo, I usually tend to ignore hack-n-slash games. I decided to play Torchlight however after I got it for free with a gaming magazine and it really took me by surprise. The game has a great artistic direction and a cartoonish design as well as a great soundtrack that adds a lot to the fairytale feeling. It features 3 classes (Alchemist/Destroyer/Vanquisher) and a gameplay very similar to the one we've seen in Diablo I / II, with a few interesting additions. Among those, one that I found very helpful is the fact that every hero has it's own pet that can sell/buy things for you, as well as the possibility to teach your pet spells and use rings, amulets and collars to give it different abilities. The game also allows you to learn spells and to fish (normal fishing as well as dynamite fishing). Every fish has special properties and it can be used to transform your pet into various creatures with different abilities. And if the standard game is no good for you, you can use interesting mods to make it the way you like. Unfortunately it has a big downside: Torchlight seams to be a game designed for co-op but without co-op. 8.5/10
