Posted: August 8, 2015
												A fantastically fun take on Diablo-style gameplay, only let down by the limited amount of content.Mechanics:The game is a procedurally generated action RPG with a heavy emphasis on loot collection, familiar to anyone who's played DIablo (it's actually made by the same devs as Diablo 1 & 2, just under a different company). You control a lone hero w/ a faithful pet as you delve deeper and deeper into a massive dungeon. Along the way you must fight hordes of monsters, including randomly spawning elites who have special skills. You can also discover hidden rooms full of treasure, solve puzzles to find treasure, and complete sidequests for treasure. Treasure!There are 3 playable classes, each of which can be built different ways via a skill tree system. You have a classic melee, ranged, & magic assortment, but with some unique twists. They're pretty good, but painfully limited. Not only are there just 3 choices, but you can't customize them at all. No apperance changes, no gender toggle, no nothing. The Destoyer is a giant hulking wrestler looking dude. The Alchemist is a skinny scientist with cool goggles. The Vanquisher is the only female character. These are your only choices, sans mods.Since the entire game is basically combat, it's vital that the combat be fun. Thankfully, it is. More than fun, combat in Torchlight is an absolute blast. I played as a summoner Alchemist and found the game to be a relaxing abnegation tool, delighting in hours of dungeon clearing and equipment upgrading.Level Design:The goal of the game is to keep clearing out a dungeon, defeating bosses along the way, until you reach level 100 and defeat the final boss. This inevitably becomes very predictable. In order to counteract this predictable progression, the game relies on randomized level design. Groups of floors (1-10, 11-20, etc) have set templates, so areas will appear congruous and monsters will change and scale over time, but the actual floors themselves are randomly generated, so the game is always throwing different things at you. This helps to keep things fresh even though you're basically doing the same task for 100 floors.You have a main quest line to string you deeper into the dungeon and three optional quest givers that always provide the same types of quests - one will reward you for killing elite monsters along the way, one will reward you for finding shards of Ember along the way, and one will open up portals to optional mini-dungeons for you to clear. In addition, such portals can randomly spawn in the main dungeon, helping to provide some variety.The floors are broken up by boss fights in set intervals, which provide exciting encounters to break up the flow of monster clearing and loot gathering. The bosses usually have unique abilities and badass appearances to make them stand out among all the other enemies. Once you beat the main story, you unlock an endless random dungeon that you can perpetually run, but I have exactly zero interest in that. It's an especially weird inclusion here, since there's no multiplayer mode for you to show off or share loot.Narrative:The mining boomtown of Torchlight is built above a rich vein of Ember, a mysteriously powerful mineral ore that is invaluable for enchantment. The Ember's power has a way of drawing people to it...including the heroes. Upon arriving in Torchlight, they meet a sage named Syl, whose mentor has disappeared into the mines. They delve underneath the town to help her find Master Alric, and soon find themselves traveling through layers and layers of collapsed civilizations. All of them succumbed to the power of Ember.The story is, sadly, the weak point of the game. It sets up an interesting world, but is itself pretty bare. You begin by venturing into the mines to find Alric, only to quickly discover that he's become tainted by Ember. Then you become tainted yourself, so the story becomes a dual quest of stopping Alric and curing your own corruption before it consumes you. This provides a rationale for why you keep dungeon-diving, and eventually provides a setup for the sequel, but Torchlight is primarily about combat rather than plot. The most effective storytelling in the game is environmental, as you see the ruins of several corrupted civilizations...more ancient the deeper you go. As shallow as the plot is, it does manage to convey this idea of power being a corrupting influence (especially if you play the Alchemist). However, it just sort of ends w/o closure. This is b/c the game was only ever intended as an intro for an eventual MMO that never got made.  Instead, the sequel provides the proper ending to this game.Aesthetics:Beautiful. The art design looks like something from a comic book, with everything appearing hand painted and gorgeously detailed. As you progress deeper into the dungeon, you're presented with older and older ruins, each with its own unique template and style. The 3 playable characters also have really cool looks. You can tell that a lot of love went into designing the world.The voice acting is dull, but Matt Uelmen's musical score is oustanding, really setting the mood for the adventure. It's slow and atmospheric most of the time, but becomes dark and brooding or energetic and adrenaline-pumping at just the right moments.Overall Rating:  4/5

Posted: December 28, 2015
												If you love action / hack'n'slash RPGs (and are old enough to remember) and prefer Diablo I to Diablo II and want some new thrill - don't skip Torchlight. Many games have tried and all have failed to extract the essence but Torchlight could successfully become the spiritual breed of Diablo. Among an ample of cool things in game mechanics, balance and combat system that is newly oldish, having just the perfect balance, you will find one of the key elements that Diablo I and II had but III did not: master composer Matt Uelmen who single handedly created the atmosphere here with his amazing tracks. Not as if GFX were on the weak side, they are just a little easy, cartoony and cheery for Matt's heavy and dark sonic texture - but that's just me, you can't go wrong with the game itself, it feels, plays and looks cool. It is like a little ninja among the 10+GB sized games: nimble, tiny (600MB or so installed) and very stabile. I played it on XP32, XP64 W7 and W8 and it worked perfectly on all the systems, not a single freeze, glitch or hiccup whatsoever. I guess, developers put an extra emphasis on bugfree coding. It plays extremely solid.Alsolutely recommended.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												When Blizzard North - the original creators of Diablo and Diablo II - wanted to start development of the third installment of the series they had a concept in mind, the concept of an MMO styled Diablo, years before World of Warcraft, in the era of Ultima Online, UO might have had a true competitor in a sprite world rather then in the 3D age.Alas it was not the desire of the company to follow that path for the series, and so several members of Blizzard North decided to go their own way. In time Runic Games was founded and with it came the true sequel game of the Diablo franchise, albeit disguised with a different name. It's name was Torchlight, and it was incredible.With the recent release of Diablo III now it's the best time to evaluate and see how different these games are. For an avid player of the previous Diablo II, the official sequel never quite felt 100% in place, now pick up Torchlight or the upcoming Torchlight II and you feel the difference right away.

Posted: July 10, 2013
												Made in large part by former Blizzard North employees, Torchlight 1 can be boiled down to a remake of Diablo 1. You're limited to a single town, forced to battle your way underground to kill an ancient evil, collecting loot and leveling up along the way. Torchlight doesn't stop there though, the loot and skills are much more fleshed out than D1, and there are infinite dungeons ingame thanks to maps that open portals to them. While the main quest is short, you can do new game +, but the main draw is the infinite dungeons. All in all a great remake of a great game, provided the cartoony visuals don't bother you too much.

Posted: November 28, 2012
												At first I had my doubts, since diablo 3 was such a let down. However this game is fantastic because while similar to the diablo series the subtle improvements and gameplay provide a very enjoyable experience. It feels like Diablo 1 and Diablo 3 combined together minus all the BS that made diablo 3 horrible. You can really tell that the orignal designers for Diablo 1 and Diablo 2 made this game! I bet they are having a big laugh over blizzard now! The pet system here is awesome too, and I love how you can send you pet to get potions or scrolls for you, or sell your extra loot w/o having to return to town all the time! Its also fantastic how 6 players can coop together instead of just 4! The online mutlipayer section is okay, and great if you have friend you always play with. I enjoy the fact our portals never go away in single player. We can also teleport directly to our friend in a multiplayer game so they do not need to constantly drop portals if a friend joins.I would highly recommend this game if you used to love playing Diablo 2 and were disapointed in Diablo 3!

Posted: January 4, 2012
												Many games have tried (with varying degrees of success) to capture the Diablo spirit and fill the vacuum that has settled in the more than a decade since Diablo 2 smashed PC sales records. But where other titles have imitated, Torchlight has abandoned all pretense and simply copied wholesale much of Diablo's content.Developed by refugees from the disbanded and reconstituted Blizzard North team that created Diablo, its hard to judge how legitimate the result is. Virtually every ability in the game can be found in Diablo 1, 2, or featured in a trailer for Diablo 3. The game follows the structure of the original Diablo so directly that you'll do a double take: your hero arrives in a town situated atop a massive labyrinth of evil, which you will descend one level at a time.It should therefore come as no surprise that Torchlight is nearly as enjoyable as its spiritual antecedents. If you have the Diablo itch and you can't for the next Blizzard title, Torchlight is worth a play!

Posted: November 26, 2010
												Diablo III is still a very long way away.  In the meantime, here is Torchlight: a high-quality action RPG developed by a lot of people behind the first two Diablos.  A somewhat refreshing take on the genre, Torchlight sports a unique and colorful visual style, along with a cheesy story that never takes itself too seriously.  There's a vast amount of randomized loot to grab in the game's 35-floor main dungeon (which is also randomized, of course), and your pet - a handy invincible companion who can fight unless its HP runs low - can also run back up to town to sell whatever you put in its inventory.  There's also an infinite dungeon, fishing, gambling for rare items, a shared stash, tons of sidequests, a level editor, achievements, Steam Cloud support, it's also on Mac, and there are a HUGE number of mods for it (google "Torchleech"; you'll be glad you did).An absolute steal.  Reccomended for anyone who likes fun.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Since I'm not a big fan of Diablo, I usually tend to ignore hack-n-slash games. I decided to play Torchlight however after I got it for free with a gaming magazine and it really took me by surprise. The game has a great artistic direction and a cartoonish design as well as a great soundtrack that adds a lot to the fairytale feeling. It features 3 classes (Alchemist/Destroyer/Vanquisher) and a gameplay very similar to the one we've seen in Diablo I / II, with a few interesting additions. Among those, one that I found very helpful is the fact that every hero has it's own pet that can sell/buy things for you, as well as the possibility to teach your pet spells and use rings, amulets and collars to give it different abilities. The game also allows you to learn spells and to fish (normal fishing as well as dynamite fishing). Every fish has special properties and it can be used to transform your pet into various creatures with different abilities. And if the standard game is no good for you, you can use interesting mods to make it the way you like. Unfortunately it has a big downside: Torchlight seams to be a game designed for co-op but without co-op. 8.5/10

Posted: January 22, 2014
												I would heartily recommend Torchlight to .....someone if they were approximately 10-12 years old and as long as they'd done their homework! Its easy, flashy,  harmless,  extremely superficial and an utter waste of time much like the entire "Diablo" formula. But that is often enough or at least  OK so to speak for a lot of people since it's based on gameplay that has a strongly addictive element especially for the naieve. I don't mean that arrogantly when I played my first computer game in 1982 it was the bee's knees... even if the dragon I was attacking on the screen was just a large number of "Ds and Xs" joined up! Now in the 21st century... if your sensibilities are for undemanding colour and movement the game will be a blast. Frankly, I found Torchlight shallow and often rather dull, especially some rather uninvolving levels deep in the mine where I plowed through enemies like I was harvesting a field of potatoes. To me it lacks something...best summed up as "context". Torchlight is shallow (rhymes with callow...oops). I want something more ....some emotional connectivity perhaps. I desire meaning, actual substance in the story, intellectual stimulation since I'm old and bored and graphics, colour and movement are just that. When it's all done right you get something special, something emotive and memorable. Challenging for a designer I know, my sensibilities get in the way of fun..oh well. Fun is however easy peasy, disposable but leads to jadedness. Torchlight has not a shread of "context" but it is likely to be fun at least.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												I haven't finished playing this game yet, but 47 hours in is enough for me to say it's awesome :D  I'm not normally a fan of dungeon crawlers - one of the main reasons being they're an overpowering world of greys and browns.  Torchlight really brightens things up and manages to keep the exploration fresh and the various mini quest, hidden dungeons and looting mechanisms are sure to keep your dopamine reward pathways edging towards the computer for more (seriously, it's addictive - if you're an RPG fan this might be one of those where you lose sleep).  On the face of it things are pretty simple - the "surface" town of Torchlight is where all the quests and side quests are acquired, weapons/armor can be enchanted with upgrades, loot like gems or potions can be transmuted into more powerful versions etc - but the game's face and atmosphere change drastically as you delve deeper into the mines of Torchlight where the *ember* lies.  Floor 1 looks a million miles away from floor 30 - both in terms of visuals and the calibre of enemies you'll encounter.  It's very easy to do these kinds of fairly formulaic games wrong - and they often come out as boring Diablo clones.  This does not feel like that.  In fact, I'm not even a huge fan of Diablo, but I love this.  The makers of Torchlight found exactly the right balance between classic RPG elements and innovative and clever hooks to keep you interested.  If in doubt, buy it while it's on sale.  But honestly, I'd say it's actually worth the RRP in terms of the number of enjoyable hours you'd get out of it.  I am biased as an RPG fan though :P

Posted: January 18, 2014
												So where do I begin with Torchlight. I guess from where everyone else will see it. This is very simular to Diablo. There I've said it. Like it or not whenever a top down dungeon crawling hack n slash loot driven game is released the first thing it will be compared to is Diablo. So having said that how does it compare? Thats a good question. I'm glad you asked that. Torchlight is a brilliant game and has stood up against the "Oh its just a Diablo Clone" comments fairly well. Granted this hasn't been as big as Blizzards long lived and beloved game but this is the first of hopefully many for this series. So lets look at why this is such a "Diablo Clone". Simple really. Part of the old Diablo team (Not Diabo 3) left Blizzard and produced Torchlight. That is the easiest way to explain that. Their style of story writing and gameplay design will obviously come through in whatever game they make. But be rest assured this is not a "Diablo Clone".Now the elephant has left the room lets get down to Torchlight on its own. It has a very cartoony graphics. Which I for one love. I find that it works really well set in a fantasy world. You don't always have to have photo realistic graphics when you have such good gameplay. Which Torchlight has plenty of. The quests you receive are both fun and rewarding. You obvisouly end up in a lot of dungeons and caves and the such trawling your way through hordes of different mobs all trying to slay you. This all leads to quite an exciting time. Working your gear set up and moves set to make sure you are ready for the next dungeon run and boss battle. There are tons of weapons to find. Looting mobs being one of the biggest parts of the game. So you'll be sure to find great weapons and armour etc to make your character even more powerful and unstoppable. You dont have a huge selection of characters to choose from but the basics are covered. Melee, ranged and magic classes. Each with there own special skill sets to work through. Each has 3 skill tress to work up to make your character even more powerful.Theres also the ability to have a kanine companion with you fighting alongside. This can sometimes be more of an pain than a pleasure. But for the most part it is nice to not be alone in dark damp mob infested dungeons. Just a small issue to be noted as I know there are a lot of MMO players out there. This is not an MMO. It is stricly single player. Torchlight 2 has multiplayer so if it is a deal breaker go try the 2nd in the series.So thats the basics. All I would say is if your a little bored of Diablo and want to try something a bit the same but done a little bit different this could very well be for you. Failing that Torchlight 2 is even better.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												It's hard to play this game and not compare it to diablo 2. But that is to be expected since the team who made this made diablo 1 & 2. the game features random loot that varies in rariety and power, they can be upgraded thru ember gems and enchants from an enchanter, allowing your favorite weapon or armor to stay useful longer. game looks good and plays better. If you like games like diablo or fate then you'll like this game.now the downsides. Camera can be zoomed in and out but not rotated which is very annoying, there are a couple of mods to correct this oversite, but it really should have been included from the start. no way in the vanilla game to respec skill points if you made a mistake, luckily one of the game designers/ programmers made a potion mod that corrects this.finally the biggest issue i'm aware of is that loot is tied to enemy level and not player level. that means late game the hight tier loot starts to peter out and doesn't keep pace with character growth or progression thru the mines. once again there is a mod that corrects this, but it should have been spotted in playtesting.all that said the game is awesome and i'd recommend you pick it up.

Posted: April 27, 2012
												There are many critiques about this game, ranging from comments like "THIS IS A DIABLO 2 RIPOFF!!" to "It's respectably unique in its own way."  In my own opinion, I definitely choose the middle.  Indubitably, this game is a derivative from Diablo 2 because many people do not realize that a few creators of this game were the original designers of Diablo 2, thus it should only make sense that this game is much similar to D2.  From my perspective, Torchlight is rich in color and original in some aspects such as merging the powers of a nercromancer and elementalist from D2 into one being: the alchemist.  While the story seems to build of it's own foundation, the gameplay is painfully like D2, making it unoriginal.  But if we really think about games these days, aren't they mostly built off of other games?  Overall, Torchlight is fun and creative in its own sense, but lacks originality in gameplay and graphic features.  Thus, I give this game a 7.3 (C-).Signing out,Dante

Posted: April 28, 2012
												If for some reason you've never played Blizzard's renowned Diablo franchise and have wondered about the fuss surrounding Diablo 3, look no further than Torchlight to answer your questions.Runic Games consists of former Blizzard employees who worked on Diablo 2. As such, it should come as no surprise that the two games are extremely similar. Unfortunately, Torchlight has a few flaws that limit its potential:Repetition. Maybe I've outgrown the dungeon crawler genre, but I couldn't shake the tediousness half way into Torchlight's 12 hour campaign. Gameplay is primarily mouse clicking and neither the enemies nor environments were varied enough to keep my interest.The lack of multiplayer severely diminishes replay value. It's generous of the developers to add an infinite dungeon, but why should the average player care when he can't flaunt his spoils or successes?I do applaud Runic's inclusion of an editor, allowing fans to prolong the life of Torchlight. Kudos to that!Grade: B-

Posted: May 12, 2013
												If you ever wondered why all your friends always loved the Diablo franchise while you absolutely hated it, you probably missed the mysterious initiation those complacent souls went through by the time those games were still fresh. Well, it's your chance again. Torchlight is your way inside the secrets of the hack-n-slash RPG's, and it surely can make you a lover of the genre, no matter how contrary to that you might think you are. It is a gem, no doubt, although it has some flaws too, but in the end, rest assured that the pros easily overcome the multiple cons. Let us talk a little about the cons. The story is not memorable, nor the characters, but we are all used to that already nowadays. Also, the game looks cartoon-ish. Even if that actually doesn’t bother as much as one could think, it’s still an issue. There are only three classes, and the characters are not customizable – except for their names and pets – but that’s not so big of a deal too. To be honest, the only real problem with the game is it being too easy overall. If you have half a brain functioning, you shouldn’t play it on any difficulty other than very hard. On normal difficulty, once past half of the game and with the latest skills at hand, one can pretty much one-click anything to death that is not a boss or a mini-boss – literally. Probably only on very hard some old good player’s awareness skills might be better than just spamming the RMB, the default character skills button – probably. We hope this game can be anything of a challenge somehow. On top of all that, the game also starts to get a little repetitive on later levels… Well, from what has been said, one can understand there are some issues, but despite all of that, the game is still so much fun it would be a shame to let it be overlooked, and nothing of that mentioned above should prevent it from being highly recommended for any kind of player. Torchlight is simple, colorful and fun. The entire monster killing and the beautiful visual effects keeps the player interested in the action. The weapons are interesting, so are the drops: one doesn’t have to go anywhere outside the run at hand for help with his survivability. Indeed, because of things like this, the simplicity of the game could arguably be a plus in its favor, instead of a detriment. If one doesn’t want to sacrifice all his spare time grinding, farming, and even buying from other players (sometimes even with real cash) only to be able to survive at later levels, like, for example, one is supposed to do in Diablo III, Torchlight offers a fantastic alternative. It is made for casual players, and anyone could play it on the hardest difficulties without having to resort to anything other than what he finds and does at that particular level with that particular character. Add to all of that the super low price and it becomes an absolute must buy, at least if you’re not a fool. Are you a fool?

Posted: January 20, 2011
												This is a charming, modernized spin off the Diablo 2 style of gameplay. If you were a fan of Diablo 2, chances are you will have no trouble deriving enjoyment from this game. It's all third person perspective with random loot and other roleplaying elements to give this game enhanced replayability. The storyline may come to an end, but the game itself is infinite. The dungeon generates an unlimited number of levels which make it possible to play this game continuing the adventure indefinitely. This isn't a game that competes well with other modern titles which offer more originality and hardware intensive graphics, but it was well worth the cost and won't soon be forgotten.

Posted: August 1, 2012
												It's a cute little Diablo / Fate clone with WoW-like graphics.  The battles are visceral enough to keep you hungry for blood, and the levels are fun to explore.  Socketing and customizing weapons is the center focus, while your character only changes looks based on what armor they're currently wearing.  I'm a big customization guy and not being able to customize your toon bummed me out.  The story is minimal, and the starting town full of NPCs is boring, making you disregard them to the point of not caring about their lives or stories.  Overall, For the price it's pretty fun, but not playing it won't have you missing out on anything.  It's a casual game for casual players.

Posted: April 29, 2014
												Playing Diablo as a yong one, I forever became a fan of hack and slash RPGs.  I've played all kinds, from all different types of systems.  But I never expected to play one on the PC that rivaled the original Diablo.  That might be big statement to make, but Diablo is old.  What Torchlight does is slightly modernize the ideal behind Diablo.  Most of the team that created Torchlight was on the original Diablo team anyways.  This shows in the game's design.The Graphics and sound quality are great for such an under the radar game.  Thats probably why this game did so well, its just good.  Yes the game is a bit shallow but thats refreshing sometimes.  This game is the ultimate inbetween game, sort of like Minecraft.  There is a story and ending like most games, but the idea of dungeon crawling and getting loot its almosta  primal earge to destroy and collect.Finally, the trush is this is more light weight Diablo.  Less of the dread and difficulty and more of the heroic deeds and pretty colors and effects.  Please give this and Torchlight's sequel Torchlight 2. Graphics -  3/5 Sound -  3/5 Control -  3/5 Misc -  3/5

Posted: February 1, 2014
												Torchlight isn't a game. It's an addiction.Everything about Torchlight is very simplistic. From the fighting (which is as simple as "point and click") to the story (which I barely remember after 20+ hrs. of gameplay). It becomes mindless, and after awhile Torchlight made me feel like a rat hitting a feeder bar. I'd *click, click, click* to kill monsters, hope for some good loot, and repeat. Playing on normal mode was perhaps a bit too easy, as I only ever died out of stupidity. Even the bosses were very easy, with the exception of the final boss who was entirely unbalanced with the rest of the game.Though I'm glad I'm now free of its grasp, I must admit that I had fun playing Torchlight. Any RPG expert will have fun balancing player, pet, and weapon/armor stats, but the actual gameplay and story will remain a bit dull.My rating: 3/5

Posted: April 6, 2014
												"I can't believe its not Diablo!" Dungeon Crawler style RPG in the same vien of Diablo and the like. It's charming low poly graphics, linear design, and creative construction between a good and well designed game and a strong support and love for modders and those who enjoy to use mods. You progress through the game with a well balanced difficulty as you follow a linear but expansive dungeon. Every few floors things change up and goes from flooded tiki pygmy's getting pushed of cliffs to volcanic subterean and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off goblins. Lots to explore but you can still maintain a solid straight through experience if you arent into all the secret finding and loot grabbing and Champion hunting goodness. Easy to enjoy, a great pick up and play. It satisying in Casual sir-gibs-alot, as well as the hard as nails Elite mode leaves you wanting to try it with all the characters. Also i totally probably wasn't a Rifle toting Alchemist with a super shield.... I've played the game alot more than i have on steam, played and beaten it before i had steam so some fore thought.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												When Blizzard North - the original creators of Diablo and Diablo II - wanted to start development of the third installment of the series they had a concept in mind, the concept of an MMO styled Diablo, years before World of Warcraft, in the era of Ultima Online, UO might have had a true competitor in a sprite world rather then in the 3D age.Alas it was not the desire of the company to follow that path for the series, and so several members of Blizzard North decided to go their own way. In time Runic Games was founded and with it came the true sequel game of the Diablo franchise, albeit disguised with a different name. It's name was Torchlight, and it was incredible.With the recent release of Diablo III now it's the best time to evaluate and see how different these games are. For an avid player of the previous Diablo II, the official sequel never quite felt 100% in place, now pick up Torchlight or the upcoming Torchlight II and you feel the difference right away.

Posted: July 10, 2013
												Made in large part by former Blizzard North employees, Torchlight 1 can be boiled down to a remake of Diablo 1. You're limited to a single town, forced to battle your way underground to kill an ancient evil, collecting loot and leveling up along the way. Torchlight doesn't stop there though, the loot and skills are much more fleshed out than D1, and there are infinite dungeons ingame thanks to maps that open portals to them. While the main quest is short, you can do new game +, but the main draw is the infinite dungeons. All in all a great remake of a great game, provided the cartoony visuals don't bother you too much.

Posted: May 30, 2012
												Torchlight was the Diablo everyone was waiting for when there were none left to be found. It has all the best from the genre with none of the negatives.There is random loot aplenty, your character develops significantly as you proceed through the game, you can combine gems to make them more powerful, and unique to this torchlight, you can even gamble on enchanting your gear; maybe it will become more powerful, maybe all of the enchants will be wiped away.Graphics are great, sound is great, and you'll enjoy every minute of it.4/5

Posted: December 17, 2015
												I'm typically not a huge fan of RPGs. In fact, I only started playing this game tody because I noticed I'd bought it two years ago and never played it. However, this RPG has a lot of things going for it. The graphics are really nice, the voice acting is decent, and it's great to be able to send your pet to go on errands for you when you're deep in the dungeon.However, this game is really small. It's one dungeon with multiple levels and one town. I found the combat lacking slightly so far, but I haven't explored many of the other special attacks available. I also felt as though there should be some form of multiplayer element to it, since I personally enjoy getting a team to game with in RPGs. If there was some sort of multiplayer and a slightly larger map I would be even more impressed with Torchlight.Overall, good game. If you don't want to spend the $15, definitely get it when it goes on sale.

Posted: July 7, 2011
												To those new to the RPG-scene, read the last line.To those looking for familiarities and differences, pro's and con's compared to other games, read on.Torchlight is a creative tongue-in-cheek mix of a few RPG's, the biggest influences being Dragonica and Fable (1.. ). The graphics are 'chunky' which often invites thoughts of 'cheapness' and 'shortcuts', but was pleasantly surprised with the detail in customization it really goes. Spells are beautiful, the combat is amazing and the monsters are just hilarious sometimes. Those who've played Dragonica will understand the artistic style straight away. The Fable-side of it is almost entirely the mechanics. Things just work.. well. There's no shortcuts taken, everything in it seems meant to be there from pets being able to take loot back to town for selling, to the myriad of mazes and routes possible for each (and every..) quest.Buy it. Buy it now. It's not only a great first RPG, it's a great RPG to stand on it's own.

Posted: August 1, 2012
												It's a cute little Diablo / Fate clone with WoW-like graphics.  The battles are visceral enough to keep you hungry for blood, and the levels are fun to explore.  Socketing and customizing weapons is the center focus, while your character only changes looks based on what armor they're currently wearing.  I'm a big customization guy and not being able to customize your toon bummed me out.  The story is minimal, and the starting town full of NPCs is boring, making you disregard them to the point of not caring about their lives or stories.  Overall, For the price it's pretty fun, but not playing it won't have you missing out on anything.  It's a casual game for casual players.
